extendedIngredients.name: bone in skin on chicken breast
carrot
extendedIngredients.originalString: 1 large carrot, peeled and quartered on an angle

extendedIngredients.name: celery
extendedIngredients.originalString: 3 to 4 small ribs celery and leafy tops, very thinly sliced on an angle

extendedIngredients.name: dill
extendedIngredients.originalString: Chopped fresh dill and parsley, for garnish

extendedIngredients.name: leeks
extendedIngredients.originalString: 2 leeks, trimmed, sliced, soaked and dried

extendedIngredients.name: meat
extendedIngredients.originalString: 2 pieces poached chicken breast, meat diced or shredded, about 2 to 2 1/2 cups white meat

extendedIngredients.name: onion
extendedIngredients.originalString: 1 onion, quartered and very thinly sliced

extendedIngredients.name: parsnips
extendedIngredients.originalString: 2 parsnips, julienned or 1 small bulb fennel, quartered and julienned, plus small handful fronds

extendedIngredients.name: ground pepper
extendedIngredients.originalString: Salt and finely ground black pepper or white pepper

recipes.title: Suped-Up Traditional Chicken Noodle Soup

winePairing.pairingText: Chicken works really well with Chardonnay, Pinot Noir, and Sauvignon Blanc. White meat is typically paired with white wine as to not overpower the flavor of the meat, so chardonnay and sauvignon blanc are safe choices. Chicken prepared with a tomato sauce or certainly a red wine sauce can and should be served with a red like a pinot noir. The Chehalem INOX Chardonnay with a 4.1 out of 5 star rating seems like a good match. It costs about 13 dollars per bottle.

productMatches.title: Chehalem INOX Chardonnay
productMatches.description: INOXÂ® takes its name from the abbreviation of the French word for stainless steel, inoxydable. The wine was created differently from most Chardonnay you've had. We think we've succeeded in expressing the crisp, steely, and fruit-rich side that we love about some Old-World Chardonnays. What makes this possible is the use of exclusively Dijon clones, exceptionally well suited to Oregon's cool climate and exhibiting a richness that does not depend on oak. INOX screams of the hallmarks of a cool climate-brightness, pinpoint fruit, and explosive aromas and flavors. We intend INOX for a full range of use, from hot weather chilling to elegant dinner complements.Quintessential INOX, with lovely white aromas of gardenia and other flowers, peach, apricot, pear, pineapple, and green apple candy showing on the nose and palate; it shows a great balance with relatively low alcohol for the year and bright acid; the length is lovely and the weight rich, with a supple, silky texture; flavors linger, with cherry and peach accents. Very pleased.

recipes.instructions: Place the chicken, leek, onion, celery, carrot, lemon, parsley, dill, thyme, and bay leaf in a large pot and fill with water until the pot is 2 to 3-inches full from the top, about 3 to 4 quarts water. Cover and bring to a boil, then uncover and reduce heat to simmer. Cook uncovered 1 hour. Remove the chicken to large plate or bowl. Strain the cooking liquids and reserve for soup stock. Pull the skin and carcass away and chop the meat or shred with forks.                          Heat 2 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil in soup pot or large Dutch oven over medium-high heat and add leeks, onions, celery, parsnip or fennel, carrots, salt and pepper. Stir frequently for 10 minutes to soften vegetables without browning them then add stock and 1/3 of the chicken meat to pot. Cool and store soup for a make-ahead meal and reheat over medium high flame or, to serve immediately reduce heat to simmer and cook the egg noodles in another pot.                          Boil water in a large pot, salt the boiling water and cook the pasta to al dente or with a good-bite left to it. Drain the pasta and toss with butter or a drizzle of oil, stir to combine and coat the noodles evenly.                          Pour the soup over the noodles in soup bowls and top with fresh dill, parsley, or reserved fennel fronds, if using.

steps.step: Place the chicken, leek, onion, celery, carrot, lemon, parsley, dill, thyme, and bay leaf in a large pot and fill with water until the pot is 2 to 3-inches full from the top, about 3 to 4 quarts water. Cover and bring to a boil, then uncover and reduce heat to simmer. Cook uncovered 1 hour.
Remove the chicken to large plate or bowl. Strain the cooking liquids and reserve for soup stock. Pull the skin and carcass away and chop the meat or shred with forks.

Heat 2 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil in soup pot or large Dutch oven over medium-high heat and add leeks, onions, celery, parsnip or fennel, carrots, salt and pepper. Stir frequently for 10 minutes to soften vegetables without browning them then add stock and 1/3 of the chicken meat to pot. Cool and store soup for a make-ahead meal and reheat over medium high flame or, to serve immediately reduce heat to simmer and cook the egg noodles in another pot.
Boil water in a large pot, salt the boiling water and cook the pasta to al dente or with a good-bite left to it.
Drain the pasta and toss with butter or a drizzle of oil, stir to combine and coat the noodles evenly.
Pour the soup over the noodles in soup bowls and top with fresh dill, parsley, or reserved fennel fronds, if using.
